head.supplied: 13th May [188]7 ¶ Sir, ¶ ¶ The Committee of Management (in conjunction with Baron Mueller) is sending Mr Bauerlen to the far north-west of this colony during the coming spring to collect plants, and ...

div.p: MRS 4/4/340-1 outward letters, Archives of Powerhouse Museum, Sydney.

To proof.
MRS 4 is called: Copies of correspondence sent: first series 23 September 1882-14 July 1921, do we need to include that?. It is n. 124/87.
13th May [188]7
editorial addition. it's a letterpress copy.

The Committee of Management (in conjunction with Baron Mueller) is sending Mr Bauerlen to the far north-west of this colony during the coming spring to collect plants, and also vegetable products of economic value, such as timber, gums & resings, salt-bushes, tan-barks &c; for the angle of this colony near the South Australian and Queensland borders has never yet been visited by a botanist.

He will leave Bourke not later than the first week in August, and is due in Sydney with his collections about the middle of October. He commences so early in order to be able to collect the earliest and sometimes most transient spring plants.

If Mr Bauerlen's journeyings should cause him to pass your station would you kindly exercise your good offices on his behalf, aassisting him when en route to or in the direction of the counties of Grey, Evelyn & Poole by conveyance of him & his specimens. Mr Eccleston Du Faur has furnished me with your name as likely (should there be any necessity for it) to assist in this this truly national undertatking. Mr Bauerlen's precise route is uncertain for it will depend partly upon the appearance of the country for the objects he has in view, and partly upon the convenience of the gentlemen to whom he will be indebted for transit.

I beg to enclose copy of a synopsis of this museum, together with a copy (under separate cover) of the Report for 1886 just presented to Parliament, which will give you some idea of the aims and objects of this Museum.

When next you are in Sydney, I shall be glad if you will visit this Museum in order that you may see what Australian products are contained in it. Very few, you will see, come from the North-west, and it is scarcely creditable to the colony that we should have hitherto remained so long ignorant of its vegetable products.

div.p:
Curator
Subsequent pages of the letterbook contain identical letters to W. Scott, Whittabrennah Station; No. 64 [see J. Maiden to M, 13 May 1887 & in following instances]; Messrs Reid & Shaw; 135; 200 & 173 Brobribb; 92; 8; 274 Kayrunnera; 283; 2; 93 Yantara; 185; 239; 80.
